subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Re: how to transcribe air and ear
msgSnippet: ... I have thought a bit more about the sit seat case, in which some users pronounce both words with the same vowel, only lengthening the vowel. It is not true
messageBody:
John Cowan wrote:
>
>
> Paul Tremblay scripsit:
>
> > I see. But what dialects make this distinction?
>
> Forgive me for not remembering: a quick googling didn't turn it up.
> In any case, the point's the same.
>
> > Are we talking about one exception or a rule?
>
> A rule.
>
> > In this case the user can either do what you
> > proscribe, or the user can write in a standard dialect.
>
> True, but I understood the idea of QS to be writing, insofar as possible,
> in one's own dialect. Note that this is not a case like writing "meet"
> and "meat" identically, since after all they are pronounced the same in
> (almost) all dialects; here we have two words pronounced differently but
> (in this dialect) written the same, something QS is supposed to avoid.

I have thought a bit more about the sit seat case, in which some users
pronounce both words with the same vowel, only lengthening the vowel. It
is not true that I would have that user use the same vowel because of a
mapping to IPA. There are some dialects in which different words are
pronounced exactly the same, and one can only tell what the word means
by context. I had an Irish friend many years back who pronounced "my" as
"me." In my own case, I pronounce "women" as "womun." The singular and
the plural have no difference for me. But I would never think of writing
both words identical, certainly not in TO, but really not in QS, either.
What would be the purpose? In the same vein, I think dialects such as
the one you describe would naturally write in a standard dialect. I
think you are bringing up a rare case, one in which some speakers
distinguish between two words with sounds that others would not be able
to hear.

My understanding is that QS does have enough phonemes to describe
everyone's dialect. If there are lots of cases in which speakers use the
same sound, but in different ways to mean a different word, that means
that there are more than 40 phonemes, and that QS is inadequate in how
it was devised and how we think of it.

Anyway, you are saying that the sit-seat people should use different QS
letters to distinguish between their words, but aren't you just
describing a variation of TO? If you say that the words are different
and that we are going to assign them letters not necessarily on how they
sound, but just to distinguish them, then we are moving away from the
phonomical basis for QS and towards the rigid spelling of TO.

>
> > Also, you have not described what you mean by phonemical opposition.
>
> You're right: I danced around the definition without making it.
>
> A phonemic opposition between two sounds exists in a given language when
> there are two words of the language, one of which pronounced with one
> sound and the other with the other, with no other differences between
> them. The two words are called a "minimal pair".
>
> Thus the sounds written "p" in "spin" and "pin" don't constitute a
> phonemic opposition in English: the first sound is used only after
> "s", the other in all other cases, so there can be no minimal pairs.
> However, "pin" and "bin" do constitute a minimal pair, and so there
> is a phonemic opposition between the "p" and "b" sounds in English.
> In the Hindi language, there are minimal pairs for all three sounds,
> and consequently three separate phonemes.

But I don't think you can really base QS on phonemic opposition. It is
more complicated than what I am suggesting. Of course, I understand that
one can use phonemical opposition without understanding the principal
behind it, but I don't see it as really a good way to describe how QS
works. Aren't you just talking about the difference between phonemes and
allophones?

Honestly, I am a bit against your using phonemical opposition to
describe QS (I don't fully understand it), but if you can make a case
for why it describes QS better than what I propose, then I would
definitely change my mind. I just read over Read's manual, and he
glosses over the problems we are discussing. He notes that words in
context change their pronounciation, so that really QS is not strictly
phonemical. But then he switches to the word "The" and how we should
write it. So he brings up a critical matter, and then limits it to one
word. I think Read did more or less envision that QS covered all the
phonemes in the English speaking world. He was wrong in thinking that
the upper class British English would serve as a model for other
dialects, and I think his limitation is causing confusion now.

On a final note for tonight, I think my proposal suggets we handle
problems on a case by case basis. If for example, we need to determine
that the sit-seat dialect needs to use certain letters to distinguish
sounds, I see no reason not to state that. We could still use precise
language. We could say that in such and such a dialect, the words "sit"
an "seat" are pronounced with the /I/, but that in order to distinguish
these vowels, speakers in this dialect should either use a standard
dialect X, or they can use the /I/ sound for X, and the /i/ for X.

Paul
